Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are effective approaches for the removal of organic contaminants from water. In this study, a combined hydrogen peroxide-bicarbonate (H2O2-HCO3 −) oxidant system was engineered for a Fenton-like process catalyzed by lithium cobalt oxide (LCO). The oxidant system integrates hydrogen peroxide oxidation with bicarbonate's dual functionality as both an H2O2 activator and pH buffer. Efficient contaminant degradation was achieved by the LCO/H2O2 HCO3 − system under neutral or weakly alkaline conditions, and the solution pH remained stable throughout the reaction, due to the presence of HCO3 −. A comprehensive investigation into the optimization of reaction parameters governing the removal of a phenothiazine dye was conducted. The mechanism driving the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which are responsible for the degradation of organic contaminants was elucidated. These ROS were identified as superoxide radicals, singlet oxygen, and hydroxyl radicals. The Co(III)/Co(II) redox pair in LCO served as the key active sites for activating the H2O2 HCO3 −. In addition, a possible pathway of the degradation of the phenothiazine structure was proposed based on ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis. The LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system shows great promise as a sustainable Fenton-like approach for wastewater treatment, with cost-effectiveness, high efficiency, environmental friendliness, and compatibility with neutral or weakly alkaline conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bicarbonate Hydrogen peroxide Lithium cobalt oxide Wastewater treatment Advanced oxidation processes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The textile, dyeing, and printing industries produce large quantities of wastewater, and they are among the major contributors to water pollution [1]. The synthetic dyes in the wastewater cause certain harm to human health and the ecological environment due to their environmental persistence and bioaccumulation, even if they are present in wastewater in extremely low concentrations [2]. Removal of the hazardous contaminants has attracted more and more attention from scientific researchers. A variety of methods are employed for pollutant removal at both the laboratory and industry levels, such as advanced oxidation, adsorption, membrane filtration, ion exchange, reverse osmosis, biological treatment, and so on [3]. AOPs have received increasing attention due to their unique advantages in recent years. They are efficient techniques that degrade target pollutants in wastewater through free radicals (such as hydroxyl (•OH), sulfate radicals (SO4 •−), or superoxide radicals (O2 •−)) and non-free radical mechanisms (i.e. singlet oxygen (1O2), direct electron transfer), resulting in complete mineralization of the pollutants rather than transfer from one phase to another [3–5]. In the AOPs, peroxides such as H2O2, peroxymonosulfate (PMS), peroxydisulfate (PDS), and peracetic acid (PAA) are commonly used oxidants for generating free radicals and non-free radicals. In these Fenton and Fenton-like reactions, the transition metal (Fe, Mn, Co, Cu, etc.) ions and oxides have been studied as catalysts of peroxides for the accelerated removal of pollutants. Among them, cobalt-based catalysts are one of the catalysts with good performance [6,7]. For example, the Co2+/PMS system demonstrates the best performance in organic degradation processes, in contrast to the PMS system activated by other transition metallic ions, such as Fe2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Ce3+, V3+, Ru3+, and so forth [8]. Commercial lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), a cobalt-based doped oxide with high electron mobility, is easy to source and cost-effective. Gonçalves et al. explored recycled LCO from spent lithium-ion batteries for H2O2 activation to degrade methylene blue (MB), demonstrating enhanced degradation of MB within 130−150 min that is possibly driven by O2 •− radicals [9]. Vargas et al. accomplished the multivariate optimization of degradation conditions of MB in the LCO/H2O2 system, and the degradation rate reached 93.3 % within 90 min [10]. Chen et al. reported the effective activation of PMS by LCO for the removal of sulfamethoxazole within 20 min, primarily driven by SO4 •− [11]. Zhu et al. demonstrated that LCO synergizes with sulfite to rapidly degrade rhodamine B (RhB), achieving 84 % mineralization within 1 hour at pH 3 under the conditions of 200 mg of LCO and 50 mg of Na2SO3 for 5 mg/L RhB substrate [12]. The degradation was driven by SO3 •‒ radicals and oxygen vacancies. In summary, the three systems perform differently using different oxidants. In contrast, the LCO/PMS system exhibits the best performance; however, this system operates under acidic conditions because a large amount of H + is generated from PMS hydrolysis, rapidly acidifying the solution to pH < 4 within 5 min, even from an initial pH of 10. The LCO/H2O2 system demonstrated lower removal efficiency and longer reaction time requirements relative to the LCO/Na2SO3 and LCO/PMS systems. Bicarbonate (HCO3 −) possesses inherent acid-neutralizing capacity and can function as a pH buffer through carbonate equilibrium regulation in aqueous systems. In addition, HCO3 − is abundant and naturally present in surface and groundwater and is environment-friendly [13]. And that, HCO3 − was found to activate H2O2 to enhance contaminant degradation by generating intermediates (HCO4 ‒, CO3 •‒, HCO3•) that are considered to contribute to the production of the ROS, including •OH, O2 •−, and 1O2 [6]. Pairing bicarbonate-activated peroxide with an LCO catalyst may enhance the contaminant removal, compared to the LCO/H2O2 system. To the best of our knowledge, no prior studies have explored LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − systems for wastewater treatment. This novel LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system likely exhibits unique advantages: (1) It possibly enhances the degradation efficiency, compared to the LCO/H2O2 system; (2) It maintains lower operational costs than the LCO/PMS system, because the cost of PMS is 27 times that of H2O2. Inexpensive oxidants are conducive to sustainable AOPS in water purification; (3) Relative to the LCO/Na2SO3, LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − is more environmentally friendly; (4) LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − may operate efficiently under neutral/weakly alkaline conditions, and the solution pH may maintain stable throughout the reaction process due to the pH-buffering capacity of HCO3 −, compared to the reaction conditions of LCO/Na2SO3 (pH=3) [12], LCO/H2O2 (pH=10) [9], and LCO/PMS system that was always in acidic environment (pH<4) [11]. These attributes possibly position the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system as a sustainable and eco-friendly alternative to the existing systems, including LCO/H2O2, LCO/PMS, and LCO/Na2SO3 in water purification. To evaluate its potential, a phenothiazine dye, toluidine blue (TB), served as the model pollutant, and the following research was conducted: (1) The degradation efficiency of the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system against four dyes, including TB (phenothiazine structure) and MB (phenothiazine structure), methyl orange (MO, azo structure), and RhB (xanthene structure). The dye structures are shown in Fig. 1 . (2) The effect of the reaction conditions, including catalyst dosage, dosage of H2O2 and HCO3 −, solution pH, initial TB concentration, and coexisting ions on TB degradation. (3) The solution pH stability throughout the treatment process. (4) Reaction mechanisms, including the main ROS and the catalytic function of LCO within the system. (5) The possible dye degradation pathways. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents Hydrogen peroxide (30 %), MO, RhB, MB, hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide, and ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium bicarbonate and TB were obtained from Shanghai URChem Limited and Shanghai Experimental Reagent Co., Ltd. LCO, benzoquinone (BQ), and furfuryl alcohol (FFA) had been sourced from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Potassium trihydrooxalates dihydrate and 4-(5-Chloro-2-pyridylazo)-1,3-phenylenediamine were from Bide Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd and Shanghai Jizhi Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd, respectively. All chemicals were used without further purification. All solutions are prepared with deionized water. The filter membrane (0.45 μm) was purchased from Jinteng China. 2.2 Characterizations The ultraviolet-visible (UV–Vis) absorbance and spectra were obtained utilizing UV–Vis spectroscopy (Varian Cary 50 Scan). Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FTIR) was recorded by an infrared spectrometer (Bruker Tensor-27). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy (Bruker EMX PLUS) was utilized to detect the EPR spectra. The degradation intermediates were detected by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS, Shimadzu LCMS2020). The chemical states of the LCO surface were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Escalab 250xi), and the binding energy was calibrated with C1s = 284.8 eV. 2.3 Experimental procedures for TB removal Into a beaker in a 30 ℃ water bath, TB (200 mg/L, 0.45 ml) and water were added. After that, H2O2 (0.3 ml), NaHCO3 (0.024 g), and LCO (0.016 g) were added in turn. The solution pH was adjusted with hydrochloric acid or NaOH solution. Water was added until the final volume of the solution was 50 mL. The reaction was carried out with magnetic stirring. Samples were collected with a syringe at 5-minute intervals and immediately filtered using a syringe filter (with a 0.45 μM membrane). The absorbance of the filtrate at 629 nm was measured using a UV–Vis spectrophotometer. The residual TB concentration and the removal rate of TB were calculated based on the standard curve of TB. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance of LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − in dye removal The performance of LCO, LCO/H2O2, H2O2-HCO3 −, and LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − in TB removal was compared in Fig. 2(a) . LCO alone cannot degrade TB. The TB removals by LCO/H2O2 and H2O2-HCO3 − systems were only 4.3 % and 10 % within 40 min, respectively. However, the removal rate by the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system reached 99.8 %. These results revealed that the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system achieves efficient TB degradation, and LCO serves as a high-performance catalyst for H2O2-HCO3 − activation. The initial removal rate constant of the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system is 0.0446 min−1. The LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system also exhibited excellent performance in removing dyes other than TB, as shown in Fig. 2(b). The removal rates of MB, MO, and RHB within 40 min were 93.9 %, 96.9 %, and 74.6 %, respectively. RHB could also be completely removed when the reaction time was extended to 65 min. 3.2 Effects of the operating parameters on dye removal The effect of reaction conditions on dye removal was examined. Fig. 3(a) shows that the TB removal increased when the H2O2 dosage increased from 9.75 to 195 mM. TB can be completely removed when the H2O2 dosage is only 58.5 mM. However, an inhibitory effect was observed when the dosage increased to 390 mM, which may be due to the quenching of active species by excessive H2O2 [14]. Therefore, the optimal dosage was 58.5 mM. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the removal rate of TB also increased with the increase of NaHCO3 dosage. It was sufficient for complete TB removal when the dosage of NaHCO3 was 0.024 g. The removal rate exhibits small changes upon further increase of NaHCO3. Therefore, NaHCO3 dosage was set at 0.024 g in subsequent experiments. Fig. 3(c) shows that the removal rate continued to increase as the LCO amount increased, and higher LCO dosages accelerated dye removal—40 min were required at 0.016 g/L, while only 30 min were needed at 0.032 g/L. This could be explained by the more active sites provided by more LCOs. In addition, considering that trace cobalt ions may leach from LCO and participate in the activation of H2O2-HCO3 −, the filtrate containing cobalt ions was prepared by dispersing LCO in a solution under the same reaction conditions, and then filtering the solution to remove the solid LCO. TB was then added to the filtrate for degradation experiments. In the filtrate, the TB removal rate was only 10 %, similar to that of the pure H2O2-HCO3 − system. Therefore, there was no effect of the trace cobalt ions on the TB removal in the system. The effect of the initial solution pH on TB removal is shown in Fig. 3(d). When the initial pH of the solution ranges from 7 to 8, the TB removal rate is the highest, indicating that the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system exhibited good performance in pollutant removal under neutral and weakly alkaline conditions, which is different from the LCO/Na2SO3 system (pH=3) [12]. The removal rate decreased when the solution pH was greater than 9, due to the conversion of some HCO3 − into CO3 2− under the alkaline condition. Chen et al. reported that the solution pH dropped rapidly in the LCO/PMS system, and pH was <4 during the reaction process, owing to the hydrolysis reaction of PMS that generates a large amount of H + [11]. For comparison, the changes in solution pH in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system during the reaction process were observed, as shown in Fig. 3(e). The initial solution pH was weakly alkaline (pH 8.0). As the reaction progressed, the solution pH changed slightly, ranging from 8.0 to 8.4, indicating that HCO3 − in the system plays a buffering role. If the initial solution pH is adjusted to 7 by hydrochloric acid or a buffer solution of potassium hydrogen oxalate, the solution pH was in the range of 7.0 − 8.3 or 7.0 − 7.7 with the progress of the reaction. Overall, in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system the solution pH remains relatively stable throughout the entire reaction process. As shown in Fig. 3(f), temperature significantly enhances TB removal, with the degradation rate accelerating at elevated temperatures. This stems from thermally promoted catalyst activation of H2O2, thereby increasing •OH generation [15]. The effect of initial TB concentration on its removal rate is shown in Fig. 3(g). As the initial TB concentration increases, the degradation rate decreases. The removal of TB at higher concentrations requires an extended time. TB at an initial concentration of 2.7 mg/L or 3.6 mg/L can be removed within 40 or 70 min when the dosages of H2O2, NaHCO3, and LCO are 58.5 mM, 0.024 g, and 0.016 mg/L, respectively. In actual water bodies, there are generally various types of inorganic anions. Therefore, the effects of common inorganic anions, including chloride (Cl−), nitrate (NO3 −), bicarbonate (CO3 2−), and phosphate (PO4 3−), on dye removal in LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − systems were investigated. Fig. 4 (a) and Fig. 4(b) showed that Cl− and NO3 − have little inhibitory effect on TB removal. However, the presence of CO3 2− or PO4 3− usually has a significant inhibitory effect on the catalytic degradation of organic pollutants in Fenton-like reactions [11]. A similar inhibitory effect was observed in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system, as showed in Fig. 4(c–d). The removal rate decreased from 99 % to 74 % and 64 %, respectively, when the amounts of CO3 − and PO4 3− were 15 mM. The inhibition by CO3 2− is attributed to the quenching effect of CO3 2− on •OH [11,16]. The inhibition by PO4 3− was due to its chelation with the active sites of the catalyst, blocking oxidant-catalyst interaction [17]. 3.3 Reusability and stability of the catalyst In order to evaluate the reusability of the catalyst, recycling tests were carried out. The used LCO was collected by filtration after each run of reaction, and it was then washed and dried. The degradation reaction was reinitiated by adding the recycled LCO into a fresh solution of TB, H2O2, and NaHCO3. The results of the three cycles are shown in Fig. 5 (a). The TB removal rates in the first, second, and third runs were 98.5 %, 98.1 %, and 78 %, respectively. The catalyst's activity change was negligible during the second run, while it decreased significantly in the third run. The deactivation of the catalyst was possibly due to the loss of the active sites of the catalyst. To test the stability of the catalyst, the concentration of leached Co ions from LCO under varying initial pH conditions was measured using a spectrophotometric method, with 4-(5-Chloro-2-pyridylazo)-1,3-phenylenediamine as the chromogenic agent [18]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), all measured values were below 0.5 mg/L, which is under the regulatory limit of 1.0 mg/L for wastewater effluent based on the Chinese national standard [19]. The leaching of Co ions is possibly responsible for the deactivation of the catalyst. 3.4 Reaction mechanism of LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system 3.4.1 FTIR of the catalyst The infrared spectra of the fresh and used LCO were compared in Fig. 6 , in order to explore the reaction mechanism through the structural changes of the catalysts. The peaks at 3452 and 1635 cm−1 are attributed to the characteristic peaks of OH of water adsorbed on the surface of LCO [20]. The bands at 607 and 528 cm−1 are assigned to the bending modes of O–Co–O and the stretching mode of Li–O, respectively [21]. Upon the reaction, the characteristic peaks shifted to 3446, 1631, 609, and 525 cm−1, respectively. The peak shifts indicated that the adsorbed water, O–Co–O, and Li–O bonds of LCO were involved in the reaction. In addition, there is a weak peak near 1400 cm−1, which is caused by the vibration of the LCO lattice [22]. 3.4.2 Identification of the ROS Gonçalves et al. proposed O2 •− as a potential ROS in the LCO/H2O2 system, though this remains experimentally unverified [9]. ROS such as •OH, 1O2, and O2 •− are typically generated in a bicarbonate-activated hydrogen peroxide system and participate in the degradation of pollutants [6]. To investigate the active species generated in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system, EPR tests were conducted using TEMP, TEMPO, and DMPO as trapping agents for O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH, respectively. The EPR tests exhibited the characteristic peaks of the TEMP−O2 •− adducts, the three (1:1:1 triplet pattern) characteristic peaks of TEMPO−1O2 adducts, and the four (1:2:2:1 quartet mode) characteristic peaks of DMPO−•OH adducts, as shown in Fig. 7(a) , Fig. 7(b) and Fig. 7(c), respectively [23]. The peak signals demonstrated that active oxygen-containing species, including O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH generated in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system. To verify the role of ROS in the reaction process further, BQ, FFA, and ethanol were added to the system, respectively, which are typically used as quenchers for O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH. The inhibitory effect of quenchers on TB removal is shown in Fig. 7(d–f). The TB removal rate decreased as the concentrations of the three quenchers increased, indicating the presence of O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH during the reaction process. The results were consistent with those of EPR tests. However, the three quenchers have different inhibition degrees on TB removal. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the removal rate significantly decreased in the presence of BQ. It decreased from 98.3 % to 57.7 % and 48.2 % within 40 min, respectively, when the BQ concentrations were only 1 mM and 2 mM, indicating that O2 •− played a major role. As shown in Fig. 7(e), the removal rate of TB decreased to 76.3 % within 40 min, when the FFA concentration reached 69 mM. Fig. 7(f) shows that the inhibitory effect of ethanol is not significant because the removal rate of TB still reached 97.0 % with only a negligible reduction, even at 34 mM ethanol. It indicated that •OH did not play a major role in TB removal. Based on the relationship between the concentrations of different quenchers and the corresponding removal rates of TB, it can be concluded that O2 •− is the dominant ROS in the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system. 3.4.3 XPS analysis of the catalyst To probe the reaction mechanism further, XPS analysis of fresh and used LCO catalysts was used to reveal valence state changes. Fig. 8(a) confirms all constituent elements. The Co 2p spectrum (Fig. 8(b)) displays characteristic peaks at 779.7 eV (Co 2p3/2), 794.1 eV (Co 2p1/2), and satellite peaks at 789.2 eV and 804.1 eV [11]. XPS deconvolution of the Co 2p3/2 spectrum revealed two peaks at 779.9 eV and 780.9 eV, attributable to Co (III) and Co (II), respectively. Upon the reaction, the Co (III)/Co (II) ratio decreased from 1.10 to 0.89, indicating the reduction of Co (III) to Co (II) in the redox reaction (Eq. (1)). The Co(III)/Co(II) redox pair (E0 = 0.95 V) drives H2O2 oxidation to O2 •− (E0 = −0.89 V) (Eq. (2)) [24]. The existence of O2 •− has been confirmed by the quenching experiments and EPR analysis. Eq. (1) showed that H2O, OCo-O, and Li-O bonds are involved in the reaction, consistent with FTIR results. In addition, the generation of OH‒ also accounts for the observed solution pH increase during the reaction. Furthermore, the resultant Co2+(Eq. (1)) reduces H2O2 to regenerate Co3+ while producing •OH (Eq. (3)), sustaining the redox cycle [17]. Additionally, Co3+ and Co2+ in sodium bicarbonate solution tended to form complexes with HCO3 −, according to Pan et al. [6]. (1) 2 H2O + LiCoO2 + e ‒ → 4 OH‒ + Co2+ + Li+ (2) H2O2 → O2 •− + e ‒ + 2H+ (3) Co2+ + H2O2 → Co3+ + OH‒ + •OH As shown in Fig. 8(c), the O 1 s spectrum of fresh LCO exhibits peaks at 528.8 eV (lattice oxygen [11]), 530.8 eV (a hydroxyl group in or on hydrated oxide/hydroxide/water [20,25,26]), and 532.3 eV (surface adsorbed oxygen (Osurf) [11]). For used LCO, corresponding peaks shifted to 529.3 eV, 531.1 eV, and 532.0 eV, respectively. Fitting results revealed a decrease in lattice oxygen proportion from 60.4 % to 46.5 % post-reaction, attributed to lattice oxygen consumption (Eq. (1)) [11], consistent with FTIR analysis. Concurrently, hydroxyl content decreased from 35.0 % to 26.4 % due to reduced H2O (Eq. (1)). 3.4.4 Possible reaction mechanism Based on EPR testing results, quenching experiments, IR, and XPS analysis, the possible reaction mechanism of the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system was proposed, as shown in Fig. 9 . H2O2 and LiCoO2 undergo redox reaction with H2O to yield the active O2 •− and Co2+ (Eq. (4)). Co2+ complexs with HCO3 − (Eq. (5)) [6], and the Co2+(HCO3 ‒) complex reduces H2O2 to form Co3+(HCO3 −) and •OH (Eq. (6)) [6,17]. Co3+(HCO3 −) oxidizes H2O2 to produce O2 •− (Eq. (7)), while O2 •− reacts with •OH, generating 1O2 (Eq. (8)) [6,27]. ROS, including O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH, degrade pollutant molecules. (4) 2H2O + H2O2 + LiCoO2 → 4OH‒ + O2 •− + Co2+ + Li+ + 2H+ (5) Co2+ + HCO3 ‒ → Co2+(HCO3 ‒) (6) Co2+(HCO3 ‒) + H2O2 → Co3+(HCO3 ‒) + OH‒ + •OH (7) Co3+(HCO3 ‒) + H2O2 → Co2+(HCO3 ‒) + O2 •− + 2H+ (8) •OH + O2 •− → 1O2 + OH‒ Furthermore, HCO3 − reacts with H2O2 to form peroxymonocarbonate anion (HCO4 −) (Eq. (9)), which is unstable and decomposes into •OH and CO3 •− (Eq. (10)) [27,28]. The decomposition of HCO4 − was initiated by the unimolecular homolysis of the eroxo OO bond in HCO4 − (HOOCOO−) [6]. The generated •OH reacts with O2 •− that is produced by LiCoO2 and H2O2 (Eq. (7)) to yield 1O2 (Eq. (8)). This synergy between H2O2-HCO3 − and LCO/H2O2 in ROS generation explains the superior dye degradation efficiency of the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system over individual H2O2-HCO3 − or LCO/H2O2 systems. Moreover, the formed CO3 •− further reacts with H2O2 and generates perhydroxyl radical (HO2•) (Eq. (11)) [28,29]. The decomposition and recombination of HO2 • yield O2 •− (Eq. (12)) and 1O 2 (Eq. (13)) [28,29], respectively. The interaction between HO2 • and •OH also forms O2 •− (Eq. (14)) [28,29]. In conclusion, the presence of HCO3 − influences the generation of ROS and produces additional O2 •− and 1O2, enhancing pollutant degradation [6]. (9) HCO3 ‒ + H2O2 → HCO4 ‒ + H2O (10) HCO4 ‒ → CO3 •− + •OH (11) CO3 •− + H2O2 → HCO3 ‒ + HO2 • (12) HO2 • → H + +O2 •− (13) HO2 • + HO2 • → 1O2 + H2O2 (14) •OH+ HO2 • → H2O + O2 •− 3.5 Decomposition of TB UV–Vis spectroscopy was used to track TB degradation by the LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system over time (Fig. 10 ). The spectra revealed two characteristic peaks, including a 629 nm signal from the phenothiazine chromophore and a 286 nm peak associated with the aromatic ring [30,31]. Both peaks' intensity decreased progressively during the reaction, indicating the cleavage of TB’s conjugated system and aromatic ring degradation. To further analyze the dye degradation process, intermediates after 30 min of treatment were identified by the LC-MS. The results and the proposed intermediate structures (P1-P7) were shown in Fig. 11 . Based on these results, the possible decomposition pathways were proposed in Fig. 12 . ROS attack breaks the CN bond of the phenothiazine structure, triggering the chromophore cleavage and the formation of −OH and −NH2 groups (P1 structure). This mechanism aligns with MB degradation, where conjugated structure disruption drives decolorization [32]. The chromophore destruction via CN bond cleavage explains the decreased absorbance at 629 nm in UV–Vis spectra. Subsequent oxidation pathways include: (1) the oxidation of bridge S atom in P1 to SO (P2), consistent with reported phenothiazine dye degradation [32,33]; (2) phenolic hydroxylation of P2 into diphenolic P3, that is a common kind of oxidation product of phenol in the Fenton-like reactions [34]; (3) aromatic ring cleavage into P4, accounting for reduced peak intensity at 286 nm in UV–Vis spectra; (4) carbon chain breakdown into P5 and P6, analogous to MB degradation intermediates [35]; and (5) destruction of benzene ring and final decomposition of P7 into CO2, SO3, and H2O. 4 Conclusions The LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system enabled efficient contaminant removal under neutral or weakly alkaline conditions, based on the synergistic effect of LCO and HCO3 −, combining with the pH-buffering capacity of HCO3 −. The TB removal (2.7mg/L) was achieved within 40 min. The Co(III)/Co(II) redox pair acts as the catalytic center for H2O2-HCO3 − activation. Three reactive oxygen species, O2 •−, 1O2, and •OH, mediate the breakdown of aromatic structures of the phenothiazine dye through oxidative degradation pathways. The LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system shows great promise as a sustainable Fenton-like approach for wastewater treatment, combining cost-effectiveness, environmental friendliness, and operational efficiency while maintaining optimal performance under neutral to mildly alkaline conditions. In addition, it should be noted that the limitation of LCO is its tendency to leach cobalt ions during operation. Therefore, developing strategies to minimize cobalt leaching, such as surface modification or the incorporation of chelating ligands, will be of practical significance for its long-term use. coredata.dc:description: Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are effective approaches for the removal of organic contaminants from water. In this study, a combined hydrogen peroxide-bicarbonate (H2O2-HCO3 −) oxidant system was engineered for a Fenton-like process catalyzed by lithium cobalt oxide (LCO). The oxidant system integrates hydrogen peroxide oxidation with bicarbonate's dual functionality as both an H2O2 activator and pH buffer. Efficient contaminant degradation was achieved by the LCO/H2O2 HCO3 − system under neutral or weakly alkaline conditions, and the solution pH remained stable throughout the reaction, due to the presence of HCO3 −. A comprehensive investigation into the optimization of reaction parameters governing the removal of a phenothiazine dye was conducted. The mechanism driving the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which are responsible for the degradation of organic contaminants was elucidated. These ROS were identified as superoxide radicals, singlet oxygen, and hydroxyl radicals. The Co(III)/Co(II) redox pair in LCO served as the key active sites for activating the H2O2 HCO3 −. In addition, a possible pathway of the degradation of the phenothiazine structure was proposed based on ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy and liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis. The LCO/H2O2-HCO3 − system shows great promise as a sustainable Fenton-like approach for wastewater treatment, with cost-effectiveness, high efficiency, environmental friendliness, and compatibility with neutral or weakly alkaline conditions.
